data.title: Grammy Nominations: Sam Smith, Beyonce Lead The Pack
data.meta_description: British vocalist Sam Smith was the hands-down favorite among nominees for the 2015 Grammy Awards, as he pulled in nods in the three of the top four categories announced Friday morning.
data.text:
British vocalist Sam Smith was the hands-down favorite among nominees for the 2015 Grammy Awards, as he pulled in nods in the three of the top four categories announced Friday morning.

Smith led the list of nominees with five nods, tying with Beyonce, whose recognition was limited to R&B categories.

Up for best new artist are Smith, rapper Iggy Azalea, U.K. rock quartet Bastille, country singer-songwriter Brandy Clark and sibling pop trio Haim.

Feted in the record of the year category were the Darkchild mix of Smith’s “Stay With Me,” “Fancy” by Iggy Azalea featuring Charli XCX, “Chandelier” by Sia, “Shake It Off” by Taylor Swift and Meghan Trainor’s “All About That Bass.”

Nominated in the song of the year category (a writer’s award) were “Stay With Me (Darkchild Version)” (by Smith, James Napier and William Phillips), “All About That Bass” (by Trainor and Kevin Kadish), “Chandelier” (by Sia Furler and Jesse Shatkin), “Shake It Off” (by Swift, Max Martin and Shellback), and Hozier’s “Take Me to Church” (by the artist, born Andrew Hozier-Byrne).

Nods in the coveted album of the year slot will be revealed shortly before 10 p.m. ET tonight on the CBS primetime special “A Very Grammy Christmas.” The 2015 Grammy Awards will be telecast on Feb. 8 from Staples Center.

Popular on Variety

A Smith juggernaut was apparent early in the day, as the 22-year-old singer scored in the big categories of record of the year, song of the year and best new artist. He also made his mark in the pop vocal fields, and will almost certainly nail down a nomination for album of the year with his Capitol debut “In the Lonely Hour, which has sold 932,000 copies to date domestically.

The alternate “Darkchild Version” of Smith’s hit “Stay With Me” was produced by Rodney “Darkchild” Jerkins.

One major surprise in the big categories announced this morning was the absence of Idina Menzel’s “Let It Go,” the hit track from the “Frozen” soundtrack, the biggest-selling release of the last year with nearly 3.7 million copies shifted to date. The tune was recognized in a nod for writers Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez in the best song written for visual media slot.

Also missing in action — at least outside the urban contemporary slots — was Beyonce’s self-titled late 2013 set, which sold 2.1 million even before the release of its bulked-up new “Platinum Edition.” However, with her latest nod, the crossover vocalist wrested the title of most nominated female artist from Dolly Parton.

Country-gone-pop superstar Swift’s smash album “1989” was ineligible for consideration because it was released after the Sept. 30 nomination cut-off. But its first single “Shake It Off” reaped recognition in three categories, including record and song of the year. Swift will compete in the big slots with Smith, renascent vet vocalist Sia, and newcomer Trainor’s breakout booty anthem.

One surprising development in a year of kudos for popular winners was the absence of “bro-country” acts like Luke Bryan and Florida Georgia Line in the country categories. Dierks Bentley, Eric Church, Lee Ann Womack, Brandy Clark and Miranda Lambert drew nods in the best country album category, while tunes cut by Lambert, Church, Kenny Chesney, Glen Campbell and Tim McGraw (with spouse Faith Hill) scored in the best country song slot.

Conservatism again reigned in the rock album and song categories, with nominations for such familiar faces as Ryan Adams, Beck, the Black Keys, Paramore, Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers and (for its controversial iTunes exclusive “Songs of Innocence”) U2.

Recognized in the best compilation soundtrack for visual media were “American Hustle,” “Guardians of the Galaxy,” “Frozen,” “Get On Up: The James Brown Story” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.” With the exception of “Frozen,” the category is dominated by oldies compilations.

Nominees for best score soundtrack were “Frozen” (Christophe Beck), “Gone Girl” (Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross), “The Grand Budapest Hotel” (Alexander Desplat), “Gravity” (Steven Price) and “Saving Mr. Banks” (Thomas Newman).

Besides “Let It Go,” nominees in the best song written for visual media category included “Everything is Awesome!!!” (from “The Lego Movie”), “I See Fire” (from “The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug”), “I’m Not Gonna Miss You” (from “Glen Campbell, I’ll Be Me”) and “The Moon Song” (from “Her”).

Best musical theater album nominees were “Aladdin,” “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical,” “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” and “West Side Story.”

Nominated as non-classical producer of the year were Paul Epworth, John Hill, Jay Joyce, Greg Kurstin and Max Martin.

In a new spin on the process, nominations in four categories were announced by Pharrell Williams and Ed Sheeran on “CBS This Morning.” For the rest of the morning, nominees trickled out on the Grammys Twitter feed via a parade of celebrity videos, with nods in all but one category finally issued comprehensively at 11 a.m.

Reactions to the nominations on Twitter ranged from “OMG” to “WTF,” as fans both ecstatic and disgruntled tracked the announcements and clogged the #GRAMMYs feed. Tweets were distinguished by an outpouring of love for British boy band One Direction; many were aghast that the act, now with four U.S. No. 1 albums to its credit, failed to secure nods in any of the big categories.

One wrote, “Who the hell is the person that makes nominations for grammy? where the heck is @onedirection? stupid awards.”

The period of eligibility for this year’s songs cover recordings released between October 1, 2013 and September 30, 2014.
